unit: Unit 7 | Inference for Quantitative Data: Means
title: The Effect of Increasing Sample Size
question_text:
Jason conducted a one-sample $t$-test for a population mean. Later, he realized that he had made a mistake when entering the sample size into his calculations. The actual sample size was in fact larger than the sample size he had used in his calculations.
How will this change the results associated with his test?

choices.text: The standard deviation of the related $t$-distribution will be larger than previously calculated.
The actual $p$-value will be smaller than previously calculated.
The power of the test will be smaller than previously calculated.
The probability of making a Type I error will be larger than previously calculated.
The probability of making a Type II error will be larger than previously calculated.

solution:
For a $t$-distribution, the standard deviation of the $t$-statistic is calculated as $\dfrac { s }{ \sqrt { n } } $ where $s$ is the sample standard deviation and $n$ is the sample size.

When $n$ grows larger, the standard deviation gets smaller. Plug in some numbers to check it out if you are not sure.

Now let's look at how this affects the $t$-statistic. The $t$-statistic is:

$$t = \frac { \bar { x } - \mu }{ \dfrac { s }{ \sqrt { n } } } $$

We have already established that the denominator of this fraction will grow smaller as $n$ grows larger. This means that when we are finding the $t$-statistic, we are dividing by a smaller number. The result will be a larger (absolute) value of $t$ than previously calculated. Again, if you are not sure, feel free to plug in some numbers.

A larger (absolute) value of $t$ corresponds with an observation that is farther from the center of the distribution. The likelihood of obtaining an observation so far from the center is smaller than before, therefore, the $p$-value will decrease.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A' is incorrect. As discussed above, the standard deviation will decrease or become smaller.

Choice 'C' is incorrect. Power is the probability of correctly rejecting a null hypothesis that is false. Increasing the sample size will increase the power of the test.

Choice 'D' is incorrect. A Type I error occurs when we incorrectly reject the null hypothesis. The probability of making a Type I error is the same as the $p$-value obtained. Therefore, increasing the sample size will decrease the probability of making a Type I error.

Choice 'E' is incorrect. A Type II error occurs when we fail to reject the null hypothesis while in reality the null hypothesis is false. As power increases, the probability of a Type II error decreases. Therefore, increasing the sample size will have the effect of decreasing the probability of a Type II error.
